name: Databento
description:
Databento makes it simpler and faster to get market data. Our self-service model allows users to instantly pick up live exchange feeds and terabytes of historical data—and only pay for what they use. Our goal is to power the world's largest finance and fintech institutions and make data accessible for small startups.

Since starting in 2019, we've raised over $27.8M in funding. Our team brings years of experience running high-frequency trading desks and includes alumni from firms like Two Sigma, Flow Traders, Virtu, and Stripe.

The SEC's latest proposals announced this week will bring the biggest changes of this decade to US stock market microstructure. Here's why. ⬇️  

1️⃣ 📢 SEC Proposes Rule to Enhance Competition for Individual Investor Order Execution (https://lnkd.in/gD9uq3-T)

> [...] the proposed rule generally would prohibit a “restricted competition trading center” such as a wholesaler from internally executing “segmented orders” [...] unless the orders are first exposed to competition in a “qualified auction” operated by an “open competition trading center.”

2️⃣ 📢 SEC Proposes Rules to Amend Minimum Pricing Increments and Access Fee Caps and to Enhance the Transparency of Better Priced Orders (https://lnkd.in/gE9NdTGy)

> the Commission proposed to amend Rule 612 of Regulation NMS to establish variable minimum pricing increments for quotations and orders in NMS stocks that are priced at, or greater than, $1.00 per share [...]

3️⃣ 📢 SEC Proposes Amendments to Enhance Disclosure of Order Execution Information (https://lnkd.in/ggdQtPNm) 

>  [The] proposal would modify the definition of “covered order” to include certain orders submitted outside of regular trading hours and certain orders submitted with stop prices. 

> The proposed amendments [...] would require the reporting of execution quality information for fractional share orders, odd-lot orders, and larger-sized orders.

These changes will drive more orders to lit markets, allowing exchanges to compete more on pricing and display sub-penny prices. Databento advocates for fairer, more transparent markets, and largely supports these proposed changes.

#trading #SEC #regulation #finance #stocks #markets #investing

One of the many reasons why Databento  is game-changing for exploratory use cases like microstructure research: you can fetch historical data in slices as small as 10 minutes, while most data providers force you to fetch the whole day (or even month) of data at a minimum. We jump to any 10 min slice of the order book in O(1). It's both cost-effective and cuts down on time spent downloading unnecessary data.

#historicaldata #marketdata #tickdata #datavendors #fintech

#MeetTheTeam: Introducing our Engineering Manager, Enda Peng!

Enda joined Databento's mission as the fastest, simplest way to get market data back in February 2022. 

"While working at a hedge fund, my team and I waited months on data acquisition. I'm excited to be helping to build a product that is essentially a vending machine for market data that cuts time and cost barriers for every market participant." 

Databento is actively #hiring. Apply to join the team that's creating the next-generation data stack for finance, backed by the likes of Redpoint Ventures , Unusual Ventures, and Tribe Capital! https://lnkd.in/gE_UykDB

Batch downloads are now over 2x faster on Databento, thanks to a recent upgrade of our storage! ⚡ Customize flat files from our web UI or API, and we prepare them for you on our compute cluster – with thousands of cores at your fingertips.

Fun fact: Our new web storage alone uses a whole 60 x #100G ports per rack, as pictured here, to keep up with its 100% all-flash NVMe arrays.

Databento posted another incredible month of growth in November! We tripled our registered users (+237%) and launched a new asset class (US equities).

#marketdata #datavendors #financialdata #tickdata #fintech

Apply now at https://lnkd.in/gxKtysNH, or earn $5K by replying with a successful referral.

🎉 We’re excited to announce that #NASDAQ TotalView-ITCH data is now available on Databento! Formats include full order book (MBO), market depth (MBP), last sale, OHLCV aggregates, and more. 

The data is captured directly at our #Equinix NY4 colo and is available over our Python/C++ clients and HTTP API. All symbols – over 8,000 US stocks and ETFs – can be accessed with a single API call. 

Sign up and explore for free ➡️ databento.com
With Databento, the future of data is "byte-sized." Wishing everyone a happy Thanksgiving – we're so grateful for your support! 🦃

Databento has chosen Transaction Network Services  (TNS) as its main partner for extranet and exchange connectivity! 

Databento chose TNS for their broad venue coverage, best-in-class network performance, cost transparency, and ability to come up with bespoke solutions for Databento's network needs — factors which align with Databento's goal to democratize market data access.

⚡ TNS's managed Layer 1 connectivity allows Databento to access US futures feeds with minimal delay of as little as 5 nanoseconds.

#marketdata #financialmarkets #colocation #lowlatency #trading

In 2022, Databento launched as the world's first platform to offer market data as a usage-based service. Thanks to our incredible team and users, we’ve reached some significant milestones in the process:

📈 220% average MoM user growth
➕ Tripled our team size
➕ 2.1 PB new data coverage

We’re looking forward to continued #growth in 2023, and we’re so grateful for your support along the way. Happy New Year!

#Repost as we head into the new year!
🚩 Do you experience any of these issues with your current market data provider?

Normalization refers to the process of exporting data in their various source schemas to a single, unified set of schemas. The main reason for normalizing market data is to eliminate differences between source schemas, making the data easier to work with.

In our experience, the normalization process is one of the most common places where data errors are introduced. If you're experiencing a few (or more) of these issues regularly, it might be time to consider switching market data providers. https://to.dbn.to/3zg6i73

#marketdata #bigdata #datavendors #fintech #normalization

We are pleased to announce our collaboration with Napatech on real-time financial data capture! Databento chose Napatech’s Smart Network Interface Cards (SmartNICs) for their high performance, lossless packet capture, and extensive API.

“Our historical and live offerings have strict requirements on losslessness and timestamping accuracy, and handling such a large volume of data – at up to line rate – is a significant challenge," said Renan Gemignani, Director of Engineering at Databento. "After benchmarking multiple solutions, only Napatech’s SmartNICs met our standards."

“We are delighted that Databento has selected our SmartNICs to address the demanding performance challenges of their packet capture infrastructure,” added Charlie Ashton, Senior Director of Business Development at Napatech.

Check out the full press release at https://to.dbn.to/3vSYu8i

#fintech #marketdata #packetcapture #infrastructure #partnership

Databento has released point-in-time instrument definitions! These include the instrument identifiers like symbol, instrument name, matching algorithm, tick size, expiration date, and more — all timestamped to when they were published to the market. 

How is this useful?

➡️ Eliminates lookahead bias from backtests
➡️ Lets you use the same code for simulation and production, by presenting instrument definitions the same way in historical and live data
➡️ Enables backtesting of strategies that trade new instruments such as options strikes immediately as they're listed intraday
➡️ Makes it much easier to maintain your own symbol mappings and security master, as well as search for all available symbols on a given venue

See our upcoming deployments and release dates at https://to.dbn.to/3BZypId 🎉

#schemas #marketdata #features #newreleases #fintech

“What I’ve really liked so far:

1. The data is amazing! Having access to this kind of data is game-changing. Before, I had to stitch multiple services with custom development, but all of the different schemas are awesome. I don't know of anyone else doing this, especially at this price.

2. The documentation is impressive. From the tutorials, the examples, and the knowledge base, I’ve learned a few things from reading the documentation that I didn’t know in the past.

Databento is proud to partner with OpenBB, an open source and Python-based platform for investment research. You can now access our data through OpenBB Terminal v2.5.0 and onwards: ➡️ https://to.dbn.to/openBB

At this time, a wide range of futures symbols on OpenBB are exclusively available through Databento's historical API, which exposes nearly 150,000 futures symbols and 540,000 symbols across options on futures, multi-leg instruments, and user-defined instruments.

Databento was selected as an OpenBB data provider for our ease of integration (multi-language support, including a Python client library), self-service onboarding, and usage-based pricing. We’ll be providing institutional-grade US equities and futures data direct from the source, as well as options and live data upon release. Users can import their own datasets into OpenBB, and Databento’s data is available for as little as $0.45 per gigabyte.

OpenBB’s terminal product is designed to democratize investment research – just as Databento is democratizing access to market data. We’re excited to power an analytics solution with a shared mission!

#OpenBB #Python #marketdata #dataanalysis #investmentresearch #fintech

Bringing a remote team together from across six global time zones is no small feat. Here are five takeaways from our #SaltLakeCity off-site on how to run an effective in-person meeting for your remote team:

1️⃣ Communicate policies in a centralized place.

We keep a single off-site policy doc which addresses common questions (reimbursements, working hours, etc.) for all off-sites and one supplementary Google spreadsheet for each off-site. A well-crafted, centralized policy doc makes it easy to kick off each subsequent off-site. Combined with a dedicated Slack channel and a primary point-of-contact for each off-site, we ensured everyone knew where to go to for info.

2️⃣ Prepare a meeting agenda and schedule well in advance. 

We shared all meeting plans in the off-site spreadsheet during the early stages of planning and made scheduling activities a collaborative, crowdsourced effort for the team. This allowed smaller divisions of our team (product, engineering, systems, etc.) to ensure meeting topics had more focus and relevance.

3️⃣ Plan for a large buffer of "flex" hours. 

It's tempting to fill the schedule with meetings but, often, most of the productive work takes place during ad hoc discussions. We found that the best balance was struck by allocating mornings to pre-arranged meetings (briefings, planning sessions, etc.) and leaving afternoon blocks open for a myriad of smaller tasks that manifest during the week.

4️⃣ Establish a few common traditions for each off-site.

One of our most successful, long-running exercises during these off-sites is a companywide "bug hunt", where we randomly form groups of four to compete for the most bugs discovered. (Many inside jokes have spun out of these bug hunts!) We've also made it a common practice to end each off-site with a retro session to reflect on what went well and how to make the next off-site better.

Having a few customs gives old-timers something to look forward to and reminisce with newer employees, and creates continuity in the company culture.

5️⃣ Explore what the city has to offer. 

SLC was a new destination for many, and we took advantage of our mountain setting by incorporating more optional activities such as bouldering and skiing.

#HFT strategy time, part 3: Strategy parameters and considerations. 
Continuing my HFT / quant example, see comments for context and disclaimers. 

A simple rule-based strategy is to buy a minimum quantity (1 lot) when the skew is highly positive and sell a minimum quantity when the skew is highly negative. Since this should be symmetric, we can introduce a single parameter k to decide when we’d buy or sell: 

skew > k → Buy 1 lot           (1️⃣) 
skew < −k → Sell 1 lot         (2️⃣) 

On minimum order quantity: 
Note that the minimum quantity depends on the trading platform or market that you’re on. In institutional FX markets, this can be anywhere from $40,000 to $1M. In futures markets, this is usually 1 contract. In equities markets, this is often 100 shares but can even be 1 share or a fractional share. 

Position, order and risk management: 
This strategy is nice because you don’t have to worry about complex order and position state management. You just let it build up whatever position you want. Because we expect buys and sells to be symmetrically distributed, you will eventually get out of position. However, realistically speaking, you might not have enough margin to build up temporarily large positions, so we have to specify an arbitrary position limit. 

skew > k and abs(pos) < 10 lots → Buy 1 lot             (3️⃣) 
skew < −k and abs(pos) < 10 lots → Sell 1 lot           (4️⃣) 

Spoofing: 
One problem with the skew is that extreme values might be spoofed sometimes, or it’s a well-known feature the price will go the other way because a big trader or algorithm deliberately moves against the direction of skew or imbalance. So we’ll can modify the above and introduce a parameter L to tell us to ignore the skew when it’s too large: 

skew > k and abs(skew) < L and abs(pos) < 10 lots → Buy 1 lot       (5️⃣)
skew < −k and abs(skew) < L and abs(pos) < 10 lots → Sell 1 lot     (6️⃣)

Next week I'll talk about overfitting + why I chose the skew function, and then we'll go into strategy implementation. Please read disclaimers below. 

(Given the effort it takes to write this out, I think I've earned the right to give a shoutout to my company here. You can get real-time, full order-book data from Databento to calculate these functions.)

The GIL will be disabled by default in Python! See Databento engineer Lou Lindley's comment on what this breakthrough means for the use of Python in quantitative and systematic trading going forward.
company_updates_collection.reshared_post_author_headline: Senior Software Engineer at Databento
company_updates_collection.reshared_post_description:
Excited to see that PEP 703 will be accepted by the Python Steering Council. Removing the GIL will avail much easier ways to write concurrent and performant code and also change the way people look at Python for quant trading.

One of the most popular beginner questions in quant finance has always been: "Which programming language should I learn?" Python will inevitably be mentioned, along with other popular languages like C++, C#, Java. And for many years, the main comeback for why you can't get by with only Python experience is because of the performance limitations of Python's interpreter, where the GIL practically reduces multithreaded code to single-threaded performance.

Another complaint used to be the challenge of maintaining a large project in a dynamically-typed language. I feel this is rooted in myths from the pre-type hint past. The longevity of large Python codebases like those at Instagram, Dropbox, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft, Bloomberg have long shown that it's possible to scale a Python codebase, with the help from static analysis tools like mypy, but also by compensating for the lack of static typing with expressive code and established testing practices.

Today, I think it's perfectly fine to be in systematic trading even if you only know Python. The language has made massive strides in performance in the last couple of years. Part of the credit goes to the Faster CPython team—see their talk at PyCon if you haven't. But we've also seen an uptick of modern projects start to take advantage of Rust FFIs and Rust in general, like Ruff, Pydantic V2, Polars, and even Databento's historical and live APIs for market data—which I've worked on for the past year with some of the best engineers I've ever met in my career.

#python #optimization #concurrency #quantfinance #trading #algotrading

company_updates_collection.reshared_post_description:
#HFT strategy time, part 4: Strategy implementation. See comments to catch up on this series. 

Why skew for this example? 
➡️ It uses order book data. Many (but not all) HFT strategies use order book data b/c it’s almost like a third dimension, revealing more about the markets than top-of-book data. 
➡️ It’s applicable to both low- and high- frequency strategies. 
➡️ It’s rule-based and easy to understand. 
(Opinion: If you use a quant trading platform, go for the one w/order book data.) 

Initial implementation: 
You can test various numbers for k and L to observe what happens. 

On overfitting: 
Notice that I could’ve introduced 2 different parameters to ignore extremely (+) vs. (-) values of skew differently. However, we only introduced one L b/c you’d expect there to be symmetry. (This isn't always the case, some markets tend to be trending in one direction for a long time & it may make sense to calibrate the 2 parameters differently.)

Also notice that I don’t have to trade only 1 lot at a time. This can be replaced with a free parameter that you can tweak with optimization. Some strategies work well with small quantities, others with larger quantities. This is partly related with something we call the capacity of a strategy. 

Strategies like this that trade very frequently tend to have lower capacity.
It’s usually easier to start small then scale it up if it is working, vs. globally optimizing a large number of free parameters. We want to keep the # of parameters as small as possible because of something called overfitting. 

Additional rules: 
Additional rules may improve our strategy. For example, let’s say we want to only buy when price is at least 1 standard deviation above and below recent history. Recent history can be something arbitrary, let’s say 30 minutes as it would capture around 5-10% daily volume, which is around the time you might expect a regime change. This takes advantage of something called mean reversion. 

Avoid the temptation to introduce free parameters for the configuration of the bands. I can artificially get very good backtest results by making the SD & lookback period free parameters and optimizing them. It may look good in a backtest, but I guarantee you the strategy will perform poorly out of sample. 

Another way to formulate this additional rule is to only buy after a price downtick or only sell after a price uptick. (I prefer this over technical indicators like Bollinger bands.) This focuses on a different form of mean reversion that’s sometimes called bid-ask bounce. Or more specifically, it’s taking advantage of the stylized fact that there tends to be strong negative autocorrelation between 1 tick price changes on all FIFO markets like spot FX & equities. 

Next week is on optimization. Read disclaimers below. 

(You can get real-time, full order-book data from Databento to calculate these functions.)

company_updates_collection.description:
Most people should stop writing RESTful APIs for financial data.

I think this trend is driven by three reasons:
1. Many newer fintech firms were inspired by the crypto exchange wave and just copied these crypto exchanges' REST APIs blindly, without having seen best practices in mature asset classes.
2. There's a lot of tooling, standards, and support around RESTful APIs, with OpenAPI/Swagger, Redoc, etc. so it's an easy default.
3. There are many high quality, openly-documented web APIs based on REST, like Stripe and Twilio SMS, so it's easy to copy them blindly too.

Folks on Databento's API team, myself included, have worked with many internal APIs at top trading firms and proprietary vendor APIs, and we've rarely seen RESTful APIs in use aside from powering simple dashboards or click-trading interfaces.

REST at its core is about manipulating entities. For example, a use case that's mostly CRUD on elementary resources, like a dashboard backend API for adding users, deleting them etc., is a very good fit for REST.

Idiomatic REST APIs avoid verbs in their endpoint paths as HTTP verbs like GET are sufficiently expressive for basic CRUD operations. But more abstract mutations like subsampling, space, merging—which are essential in electronic trading—are hard to express in this manner.

In the words of my colleague Renan Gemignani: once you start doing things involving multiple resources (e.g. datasets, venues, symbology type, schemas, formats, symbols) at once and across multiple domains (e.g. resolve symbols, fetch this range and merge these CUSIPs and then submit this batch job with output symbols remapped to native exchange IDs), your REST endpoints become either unnecessarily complicated, too rigid, or unexpressive.

It's awkward to force entities like schemas (top-of-book, MBO, OHLCV, etc.), symbols, dates, etc. to become resource-oriented. Neither do they really behave as simple sorts and filters that typically get treated as query parameters under RESTful convention.

What are some indirect symptoms of your vendor fighting REST conventions? I've seen several, e.g. 
- Their API forces you to query 1 symbol or 1 date at a time.
- Their API has a much larger API surface than a raw feed's wire protocol. 
- Their API introduces nearly duplicate interfaces to deal with different asset classes or multi-symbol and full-venue scenarios.
- Their API has a disorderly, deeply-nested structure of URL parameters.
- It's unpredictable how more abstract mutations like subsampling, space, merging are expressed.

In our case, we opted for a more flexible, RPC-style HTTP API. A good HTTP API doesn't have to be RESTful. Slack's API is a great example of a HTTP API that isn't—it's based on a JSON RPC style instead. gRPC has a fallback protocol based on protobufs over HTTP.

The end result is an API with a small surface of orthogonal methods and very little overlap between them.

#restapi #http #apis #marketdata #algotrading #crypto

company_updates_collection.reshared_post_description:
“How do you break into HFT or quant trading?” You’re not gonna like my answer but here goes nothing: 

There’s only ~20 “large” HFT firms out there that employ over 500 people. Most of these employees don’t do HFT, but serve in supporting roles or on non-HFT teams. Some firms have a 1:1 ratio of legal/compliance folks to quant researchers. 

Given that these firms receive thousands of resumes each week, here’s my candid advice in chronological order: 

1️⃣ Go to an elite college and study CS, math, or physics. CS > DS. DS is just an easier, less-organized CS as most schools. 
2️⃣ Participate in a “crash course” offered by a quant firm: Citadel’s Datathon, Jane Street INSIGHT or FOCUS, Two Sigma New Seekers Summit, etc. 
3️⃣ Enter a trading competition. Cornell, MIT, UChicago, UToronto all have trading competitions sponsored by top HFT firms. 
4️⃣ Slightly tangential, but enter a college poker tournament (or poker-themed competition like MIT Pokerbots) that has HFT sponsors. 
5️⃣ Join or start your school’s quant trading club. Many companies, including Databento, can provide free data & resources for your club. Writing a case study on quant trading also helps. 
6️⃣ Do a Kaggle competition by Jane Street, Optiver, etc. 
7️⃣ Do an externship or co-op if your school + target quant firms sponsor it. If they don't, give your school a list of companies to reach out to. 
8️⃣ Do an internship in a related field, e.g. Bloomberg, CME, Pico, etc. 
9️⃣ Utilize all of these opportunities to score an internship at a top-tier quant or HFT firm. Now that your foot is in the door, many other doors will automatically open. You’ve made it. 

As you can see, the easiest way to break into quant trading is while you're in college. If you’re already a working professional, it’s 10x harder, but you can still try your luck by:
- Going back to school for a master’s degree, e.g. CMU MSCF, Berkeley MFE, etc. 
- Winning a Kaggle competition by Jane Street, Optiver, etc. 
- Applying for a middle- or back-office role, e.g. software engineer, legal, HR, etc. 
- Applying at a less competitive location. 
- Working in a related field, e.g. Bloomberg, CME, Pico, etc. 

I tried to be as thorough and honest as possible. Is there anything I missed? Curious to hear your thoughts below!

company_updates_collection.reshared_post_author_headline: Senior Software Engineer at Databento
company_updates_collection.reshared_post_description:
One common question I've been getting is how to use order book data or MBO, outside of HFT. 

1. It allows you to properly sequence the backtest or simulation of any strategy or execution algo that uses passive orders.

2. Almost all order book feeds provide visibility of every level in the book, which is useful for estimating things like capacity, sweep cost and slippage. This is meaningful if you trade large size or sparse instruments, not necessarily on a low latency basis.

3. Incremental deltas are a more efficient format than book level snapshots, hence better for performance optimization.

4. Some venues exclusively use an incremental order book feed as their main or only feed, so you have no choice but to start from one anyway.

5. Because order book feeds are ubiquitous, it's easier to write software abstractions that just purely consume order book data at any venue rather than a platform that has to handle a mix of price level feeds and MBO.

6. In the context of US equities, top-of-the-book data from the SIPs, which are typically associated with "TAQ" or "L1 data", leave out a lot of liquidity information compared to the order-based prop feeds: odd lots, non-top level at each venue, and trade aggressor side, imbalance, etc. Odd lots are particularly of interest make up about half of US market liquidity and will continue to grow in share. Trade side inference with rule-based approaches are not very accurate, e.g. the classical Lee-Ready algorithm is only accurate to 70~80%.

7. There are a few widely-known classes of features that cannot be constructed perfectly from level-based data, e.g. book pressure, and will give a trivial increase in your model R^2 or other fit measures. For certain mid-frequency strategies, your top competitors are all using these so it becomes a necessity if you want to gain enough edge over them.

company_updates_collection.reshared_post_author_headline: Building data APIs at Databento
company_updates_collection.reshared_post_description:
The addition of the 6 new #Bitcoin ETFs today reminds me of a very important feature in trading systems that I see many trading firms and data vendors get wrong: how to handle intraday listings. Why is this important?

1. Supporting intraday listings mean you can start trading a symbol as soon as it  becomes available. I've seen a number of inquiries on whether Databento will add the 6 new Bitcoin ETFs—and yes, we do.

2. This is especially important in derivatives where expirations happen all of the time, and options where new strikes get added intraday when the underlying moves. On CME which has weekly trading sessions, we see a net increase of 120k+ symbols over the course of the session—that's many symbols you can't quote if we wait till post-session to add these symbols.

3. It's important for consistency between real-time and historical data, i.e. "point-in-time" data, meaning our instrument definitions are actually timestamped to the nanosecond so you know when they were actually made available.

There's a crucial subtlety here. As point 2 states, it's bad for the symbol to only get added to your system/data after the trading session when it was listed, so what I've seen some data providers—and trading firms—do is to add them at the end of the trading session but backdate it in their historical data and retroactively include that symbol in their historical data!

Meaning, symbol S gets listed at 2024-01-11T09:30, but they'd wait till 2024-01-11T20:00 to kick off an ETL pipeline that will add an entry that says S was available since 2024-01-11! (Yes, it was to the rest of the world, but to your team, it was only available on 2024-01-12.)

Arguably, having this kind of point-in-time data is even worse than missing out on the symbol for a day, because your backtests will always assume you were operationally capable of trading new listings on the day they were added, when you actually weren't!

4. Some trading venues (*cough* KRX?) do weird things to you, so your system should safeguard against them changing the tick size intra-session, or against them using ephemeral instrument IDs that rotate, conflict, or get reused. A lot of the trading platform logic to support intraday listings will also help you mitigate these issues.

#marketdata #algotrading #equities #ETFs #options #futures #CME #nyse

On May 21, we're updating how our client libraries and APIs handle the `display_factor` and `unit_of_measure_qty` fields in our definition schema.

These values are encoded in fixed-point integer format by default, but they can now be deserialized or converted into decimals using Databento's `pretty_px` or `price_type' parameters. Fixed-point integers are explicitly scaled by a factor of 1e9 (e.g., 1250000000), whereas decimal representations are implicitly scaled by 1/1e9 (1.25). 

Read more in our announcement: https://to.dbn.to/4bvtKwK

Introducing TsetlinMarketViewFX, a realtime microprice extraction system for limit orderbooks and high-frequency estimator of future prices given higher order information of imbalances in orderbook data.  

We couple a recently developed realtime sequence encoder and predictor, Hypervector Tsetlin Machines, with Stoikov's microprice estimation to adjust future price estimations using orderflow from higher price ranks.

Classically, to understand what the "true" future price would be given the current best bid and ask was to formulate a weighted price based on current spread and the imbalance in orders at the best bid and ask. 

However, this is rarely a true reflection of the next matching orders as order sizes tend to be amended or even canceled completely due to many reasons like market spoofing or informed market taking. 

Code for microprice estimation available on my github. Paper with empirical studies coming soon.

In the video, we show Tempus AI Inc (ticker TEM) on the week of the IPO, where heavy market spoofing can take place, with very large spreads an illiquidity. Orderbook data courtesy of #databento

Excited to meet everyone in NY, Chicago, and Houston!

Big news: Sweeping microstructure changes to US equities and Reg NMS: 

1️⃣ Half-penny tick size for stocks priced above $1 and time-weighted average spread below $0.015.
This is a simpler variation of the rules proposed in 2022, which would've added variable tick sizes for 3 conditions.

2️⃣ Primary listing exchanges, and by extension, SIPs, until their retirement, required to disseminate minimum pricing increment for each NMS stock.
Most equities traders hardcode their tick sizes. Rather inconvenient. A win for systematic trading folks.

3️⃣ Consolidated feeds will designate best odd lot order (BOLO).
About 50% of available resting liquidity is below round lot quantity today—a widening rift in value of SIPs vs. prop feeds. The adopted rules unfortunately don't require all odd lot information to be provided as regulatory data, a compromise to make consolidated data volume manageable.

A useful insight was that the SEC implemented a simulated, MDIR-compliant competing consolidator feed from the prop feeds, which it found provided better prices than the exclusive SIPs most of the time. This is no secret to market makers, who pick up the prop feeds not merely for the latency advantage to spray their ISOs, but also more accurate, aggregated book imbalance signals. (It's also why we took an unconventional path at Databento and avoided integrating the cheaper SIPs like most everyone else—we see a significant competitive advantage down the road.)

4️⃣ Existing CTA/UTP SIPs will be retired.
Buried in all the litigation and legal challenges to the MDIR up to this point is that there was little prior discussion on the timetable for the retirement of the CTA/UTP SIPs.

We wrote about this in Databento's last SEC comment letter, referencing Exchange Act Release No. 90610, 86 FR 18596, 18701 (April 9, 2021).

This latest release preempts the retirement of the exclusive SIPs and confirms a position that's consistent with Databento's interpretation of the MDIR. (But it's quite likely that CTA/UTP, or their successors, will themselves seek to register as competing consolidators.)

The next big fight is how consolidated market data is licensed and how SROs assess fees on competing consolidators for regulatory data—fees that will practically pass on to end users. It's expected that some parties will put up challenges on pricing/licensing to keep the frictions that existed under the exclusive SIPs' framework. Things like pro vs. non-pro, display vs. non-display, etc. This would effectively hamstring much of the MDIR through commercial terms.

Databento advocates for a fee simple regime where existing prop feeds may be used for competing consolidation—which would be most favorable to market participants—write in and support our position!

Learn more about major upcoming changes to US #equities microstructure and, as we near the retirement of the exclusive CTA/UTP SIPs, how #Databento is picking up the fight and advocating for better consolidated US equity market data in our latest SEC comment letter.

➡️ Databento's SEC comment letter: https://lnkd.in/g-cM-ztA

➡️ SEC adopting release: https://lnkd.in/gTE262vJ

What's corporate actions data? A corporate action is any company event that significantly alters a company’s share price or listing status. The exact dates and timing of these events are crucial, so a good corporate actions dataset needs to present them in a machine-readable format that’s easy to parse.

Learn more: https://to.dbn.to/3ZDNdIS

#dividends #splits #mergers #acquisitions #IPOs
